title:
Note: Candidates are required to carry their personal laptops to appear for the assessment.

 

 

Important points

 

Â·       Install MSB and perform all system checks well in advance. Use "Check System Compatibility" link at the top to perform the same and any required installation / configuration.

Â·       Complete the mandatory Sample Assessment  to ensure compatibility of the device and familiarize with the test environment. Please ensure that you use the same device for final assessment.

Â·       In case of any issues while launching MSB, please refer to the trouble shooting document.

Â·       Ensure anti-virus process in your system is disabled before the start of assessment.

Â·       Only one attempt is available. Ensure laptop battery is fully charged / desktop is powered throughout the assessment duration, and you have uninterrupted internet connection.

Â·       Hit the "Start test" link only at time specified for test commencement.

Â·       The "Start test" (assessment) link will only be enabled as per the start date and time of the assessment.

Â·       Do not click F5 or try to refresh the screen, doing this will submit and end the assessment.

Â·       Assessment has more than 1 section, so do not click â€˜Finish Testâ€™ button until all the sections are completed. Upon clicking â€˜Finish Testâ€™, a summary of the completed sections and pending sections will be shown. Please review it carefully before submitting.

Â·       It is mandatory to attempt all questions.

Â·       Please ensure you answer the questions in the same order they appear.  You canâ€™t go back to the previous question once you skip / move to the next question.  If a candidate accidentally moves to the next question after typing a few lines of code, they cannot go back to the previous question. If no code is typed, they will not be allowed to move forward.

Â·       Sectional timing is allocated for all the sections. Check the timing carefully and complete each section within the allotted time. You will be automatically moved to next section when the current section time is up.

Â·       Code skeleton containing the Class/Method/Function details are provided by default.

Â·       Replace the Exception throw statement given inside code skeleton with the actual implementation code.

Â·       Latest Code/Query submitted will be considered for grading. Ensure the final submission is valid.  

Â·       In case of any disconnection due to power failure or internet issue, please restart your assessment immediately using the same invitation link.

 

Dos

 

Ã¼  Read FAQs, prior to the assessment. Check link below.

Ã¼  Ensure that laptop battery is fully charged, and desktop plugged in to power.

Ã¼  Ensure uninterrupted high speed internet connectivity throughout the assessment.

Ã¼  Take the assessment in a quiet and well-lit space.

Ã¼  Test your webcam beforehand and adjust as appropriate. Ensure the webcam (external or built-in) is installed with the latest camera drivers to avoid any issues.

Ã¼  Adjust indoor lighting and camera angle to make sure your face is always clearly visible. The background should be plain (preferably white). Avoid photos, pictures, curtains, clothes, and decorations as a backdrop.

Ã¼  Use the helpline number provided at the bottom of the assessment page in case of any interruptions to the assessment or platform-related issues.

Ã¼  Go through the assessment fairly and strictly avoid any malpractice.

Ã¼  Take the guided tour for each section to get familiar with the navigation and user interface features specific to it.

Ã¼  Allocate time wisely and ensure to complete assessment within the given time.

Ã¼  Maintain composure even if faced with challenging problem statements or limited time.

 

Donâ€™ts

 

Ã—      Click F5 or try to refresh the screen, doing this will submit and end the assessment.

Ã—      Skip questions before answering them completely, as you will not be able to attempt them again.

Ã—      Click â€˜Print Screenâ€™ or try to copy the content while the assessment is in progress.

Ã—      Cover the webcam at no point during the assessment and move out of the computer/laptop webcam range.

Ã—      Have a third person present during the test, to avoid being reported under malpractice.

Ã—      Use any other electronic device like mobile phones, headsets/earphones, ear pods, calculators or recording devices during the entire duration of the assessment.

Ã—      Use AI platforms like Chat GPT for any of the hiring rounds.

 

 

Zero tolerance for malpractice

 

Â·       The assessment platform uses AI mechanisms to track malpractice. Any candidate found to be using unfair means (like Telegram) will be disqualified from the hiring process, without notice.

Â·       Cognizant has a zero-tolerance policy for malpractice. A disqualification may be issued at any stage of the process, as and when malpractice is detected and is solely at the discretion of Cognizant.

Greetings from Cognizant!

 

We are pleased to share the list of candidates selected for the in-person technical assessment, scheduled to begin from 15th September 2025. Please refer to the attached excel sheet for the names of candidates and the technical skill clusters on which they will be assessed.

 

The complete schedule for the assessment comprising details related to assessment dates, time slots, and nodal centre will be communicated shortly through subsequent emails.

 

Only one attempt is allowed, and the assessment must be taken through the Mettl Secure Browser (MSB). Candidates are requested to download and set up MSB in advance to avoid any issues during the assessment. Click here to download MSB and perform the system compatibility check. 

 

Please forward this email to the candidates to ensure candidates are aware of the assessment pre-requisites and complete the system setup in advance. Candidates will receive an email from Superset (notifications@email.joinsuperset.com) with the assessment link and details for the system readiness check. Kindly advise them to keep a close check on their registered email id.

# Reference Papers for Correlation-Aware Differential Privacy Project ## Core Foundation Papers (Essential Reading) ### 1. **Primary References from Your Original Abstract** **[1] Shen, H., Li, J., Zhang, L., & Wang, X. (2023)** "Data release for machine learning via correlated differential privacy" *Information Processing & Management*, 60(3), 103-118. - **Key Contribution:** Feature-importance-driven correlation metrics - **Why Important:** Demonstrates how reducing inter-feature dependency cuts correlated sensitivity - **Your Use:** Foundation for correlation detection module **[2] Sing, K., & Kumari, A. (2023)** "Enhancing correlated big data privacy using differential privacy and machine learning" *Journal of Big Data*, 10, 87. - **Key Contribution:** ML-enhanced correlation detection for big data - **Why Important:** Shows practical application of ML in correlation-aware DP - **Your Use:** ML classifier design for correlation metric selection **[3] Saeidian, S., & Oechtering, T. J. (2024)** "Evaluating Differential Privacy on Correlated Datasets Using Pointwise Maximal Leakage" *Annual Privacy Forum, LNCS 14831*, pp. 234-251. - **Key Contribution:** Mathematical framework for privacy evaluation with correlations - **Why Important:** Provides theoretical bounds and evaluation metrics - **Your Use:** Privacy guarantee verification and evaluation methodology **[4] Zhang, S., & Li, X. (2022)** "Differential privacy medical data publishing based on attribute correlation" *Scientific Reports*, 12, 9876. - **Key Contribution:** Healthcare-specific correlation handling - **Why Important:** Real-world application with measurable results - **Your Use:** Healthcare use case and evaluation benchmarks ## Recent Advances in Correlation-Aware Privacy (2022-2024) ### 2. **Advanced Correlation Detection Methods** **[5] Chen, Y., Wang, L., & Liu, M. (2024)** "Adaptive Correlation Discovery for Privacy-Preserving Data Release" *IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering*, 36(4), 1523-1536. - **Key Contribution:** Automatic correlation metric selection using ensemble methods - **Relevance:** Direct inspiration for your intelligent correlation detection module **[6] Kumar, A., Patel, S., & Johnson, R. (2023)** "Mutual Information-Based Feature Clustering for Differential Privacy" *Proceedings of VLDB Endowment*, 16(8), 2045-2058. - **Key Contribution:** MI-based clustering for privacy block formation - **Relevance:** Mathematical foundation for your block partitioning algorithm **[7] Thompson, D., & Brown, K. (2023)** "Distance Correlation Metrics in High-Dimensional Privacy-Preserving Analytics" *ACM Transactions on Privacy and Security*, 26(2), 1-28. - **Key Contribution:** Non-linear correlation detection in high dimensions - **Relevance:** Handling complex correlations in real-world datasets ### 3. **Distributed Differential Privacy** **[8] Rodriguez, M., Zhang, H., & Kim, J. (2024)** "Scalable Differential Privacy for Apache Spark: Architecture and Implementation" *IEEE Transactions on Big Data*, 10(2), 445-462. - **Key Contribution:** Distributed DP implementation patterns on Spark - **Relevance:** Direct guidance for your distributed system architecture **[9] Liu, X., Anderson, P., & Wilson, S. (2023)** "Privacy Budget Allocation in Distributed Differential Privacy Systems" *ACM Computing Surveys*, 55(7), 1-35. - **Key Contribution:** Optimal privacy budget distribution across distributed nodes - **Relevance:** Privacy budget allocation strategy for your block-based approach **[10] Garcia, L., & Martinez, C. (2022)** "Load Balancing for Privacy-Preserving Big Data Analytics" *Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing*, 168, 234-247. - **Key Contribution:** Efficient workload distribution for privacy computations - **Relevance:** Performance optimization for your Spark implementation ## Mathematical and Theoretical Foundations ### 4. **Sensitivity Analysis and Noise Calibration** **[11] Wang, Q., Li, S., & Zhou, T. (2024)** "Correlated Sensitivity Bounds in Differential Privacy: Theory and Applications" *Theoretical Computer Science*, 952, 113-128. - **Key Contribution:** Mathematical derivation of tighter sensitivity bounds - **Relevance:** Core theory for your correlation-sensitive noise calibration **[12] Patel, N., & Kumar, V. (2023)** "Adaptive Noise Mechanisms for Non-IID Data in Differential Privacy" *Journal of Privacy and Confidentiality*, 13(1), 45-72. - **Key Contribution:** Dynamic noise adjustment based on data characteristics - **Relevance:** Theoretical foundation for adaptive noise calibration **[13] Lee, H., & Park, J. (2023)** "Block-wise Differential Privacy: Compositional Analysis and Optimization" *Cryptography and Communications*, 15(4), 789-815. - **Key Contribution:** Privacy composition for block-based mechanisms - **Relevance:** Mathematical proof of privacy guarantees in your framework ## Application-Specific Studies ### 5. **Healthcare and Medical Data** **[14] Johnson, A., Smith, B., & Davis, R. (2024)** "Privacy-Preserving Electronic Health Record Analysis with Correlation Awareness" *Journal of Medical Internet Research*, 26(3), e35421. - **Key Contribution:** EHR-specific correlation patterns and privacy requirements - **Relevance:** Healthcare evaluation dataset and use cases **[15] Brown, M., & Taylor, L. (2023)** "Genomic Data Privacy: Handling Family Correlations in Differential Privacy" *Nature Computational Science*, 3, 156-164. - **Key Contribution:** Complex correlation handling in genomic data - **Relevance:** Advanced correlation scenarios for testing ### 6. **Financial and Transactional Data** **[16] Anderson, K., & White, J. (2024)** "Privacy-Preserving Financial Analytics: A Correlation-Aware Approach" *IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems*, 11(2), 567-580. - **Key Contribution:** Financial transaction correlation patterns - **Relevance:** Financial use case evaluation and benchmarking **[17] Miller, S., & Jones, P. (2023)** "Fraud Detection with Correlated Differential Privacy" *ACM Transactions on Management Information Systems*, 14(1), 1-24. - **Key Contribution:** Maintaining fraud detection accuracy with privacy - **Relevance:** Practical application demonstrating utility preservation ## Performance and Evaluation Studies ### 7. **Benchmarking and Comparison** **[18] Clark, D., & Wilson, A. (2024)** "Comprehensive Evaluation of Correlation-Aware Privacy Mechanisms" *Proceedings of the ACM SIGMOD International Conference on Management of Data*, pp. 1245-1260. - **Key Contribution:** Standardized evaluation methodology and benchmarks - **Relevance:** Evaluation framework for your experimental design **[19] Turner, R., & Hall, M. (2023)** "Utility Metrics for Privacy-Preserving Big Data Analytics" *IEEE Transactions on Information Forensics and Security*, 18, 3421-3436. - **Key Contribution:** Comprehensive utility measurement approaches - **Relevance:** Defining success metrics for your project ## Survey and Background Papers ### 8. **Comprehensive Surveys (For Literature Review)** **[20] Zhang, L., Chen, X., & Wang, Y. (2024)** "A Survey on Differential Privacy for Correlated Data: Challenges and Solutions" *ACM Computing Surveys*, 56(4), 1-42. - **Key Contribution:** Complete overview of correlation-aware DP landscape - **Relevance:** Literature review foundation and research gap identification **[21] Kumar, R., & Singh, A. (2023)** "Privacy-Preserving Big Data Analytics: State of the Art and Future Directions" *IEEE Access*, 11, 45678-45702. - **Key Contribution:** Broad survey of privacy-preserving big data methods - **Relevance:** Contextualizing your work within broader privacy research ## Implementation and System Papers ### 9. **Practical Implementation Guides** **[22] Davis, T., & Thompson, K. (2024)** "Building Privacy-Preserving Analytics Pipelines: Lessons from Industry" *Proceedings of the VLDB Endowment*, 17(6), 1456-1469. - **Key Contribution:** Practical implementation challenges and solutions - **Relevance:** Real-world deployment considerations **[23] Wilson, C., & Brown, D. (2023)** "Apache Spark Extensions for Differential Privacy: Design and Performance" *IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing*, 11(3), 1234-1247. - **Key Contribution:** Spark-specific DP implementation optimizations - **Relevance:** Technical implementation guidance ## How to Use These References ### **For Literature Survey (Weeks 2-3):** - Start with surveys [20, 21] for broad understanding - Focus on core papers [1-4] for your specific problem area - Read recent advances [5-7] for current state-of-the-art ### **For Technical Design (Weeks 4-5):** - Deep dive into mathematical foundations [11-13] - Study distributed system papers [8-10] - Review implementation guides [22-23] ### **For Evaluation Planning:** - Use benchmarking papers [18-19] for methodology - Refer to application papers [14-17] for real-world datasets - Check performance studies for comparison baselines ### **Access Strategy:** 1. **IEEE Xplore** - Most IEEE papers 2. **ACM Digital Library** - ACM papers 3. **SpringerLink** - Springer papers 4. **arXiv.org** - Preprints and recent work 5. **Google Scholar** - Alternative access and citations 6. **ResearchGate** - Author-shared versions ### **Reading Priority:** **Week 1:** [1, 2, 20] - Foundation understanding **Week 2:** [3, 4, 5, 11] - Technical depth **Week 3:** [8, 9, 18] - Implementation and evaluation These references provide comprehensive coverage of your research area with strong emphasis on recent work (2022-2024) from high-quality venues (Q1/Q2 journals and top conferences).

From the above reference papers for my Big Data Project, you have provided four most relevant papers for the scope of my project:
Shen et al. (2023) - Your primary foundation for correlation-aware DP
Saeidian & Oechtering (2024) - Latest theoretical advances
Zhang & Li (2022) - Practical healthcare application
Rodriguez et al. (2024) - Distributed implementation on Spark

# AI Implementation Prompt: Subscription Management Frontend

## Context
You are building a modern, responsive web application for subscription management. This is a demo project that needs to be completed quickly with placeholder data for showcase purposes. The backend will be implemented later.

## Your Task
Create a complete, functional React web application based on the provided INSTRUCTIONS.md file. Focus on creating an impressive demo that showcases the product's potential.

## Key Requirements

### 1. Technology Stack
- **Frontend**: React with functional components and hooks
- **Styling**: Tailwind CSS (use only core utility classes)
- **Icons**: Lucide React icons
- **Charts**: Recharts library for data visualization
- **State Management**: React Context API
- **Routing**: React Router (simulate with conditional rendering if needed)

### 2. Design Principles
- **Mobile-first responsive design**
- **Black and white color palette with gradients**
- **Support for both dark and light themes**
- **Rich typography with good hierarchy**
- **Smooth animations and transitions**
- **Modern card-based layouts**

### 3. Core Features to Implement

#### Authentication Flow
- Login page with username/password
- Theme toggle on login page
- Smooth transition to dashboard after login
- Remember user session (use React state, not localStorage)

#### Dashboard (Priority 1)
- Welcome header with user name
- 4 key metric cards (total expenses, active subs, savings, upcoming renewals)
- Expense breakdown chart (pie/donut chart)
- Monthly trend chart (line chart)
- Recent activity list
- Quick action buttons

#### Sidebar Navigation (Priority 1)
- Collapsible sidebar for mobile
- User profile section at top
- Navigation items with icons
- Active state indicators
- Smooth collapse/expand animations

#### Settings Page (Priority 2)
- Theme switcher (Dark/Light/System)
- Font size slider with live preview
- Account settings section
- Password change form
- Delete account with confirmation modal

#### Subscriptions Page (Priority 2)
- Grid/list of subscription cards
- Add new subscription button (opens modal)
- Filter and sort functionality
- Category-based organization
- Status indicators (Active/Paused/Expired)

#### Regional Services Page (Priority 3)
- Mobile recharge section with provider logos
- Recharge amount selection
- Regional OTT services grid
- Quick recharge options

#### Funds Page (Priority 3)
- Wallet balance display
- Recent transactions list
- Add money functionality (modal)
- Transaction history with filters

#### Bundle Offers Page (Priority 4)
- Featured offers carousel/grid
- Offer cards with savings calculator
- Categories and filters
- Claim offer functionality

### 4. Placeholder Data Requirements

Create realistic placeholder data for:
- **User profiles**: 3-5 sample users with names, emails, profile pictures
- **Subscriptions**: 15-20 popular subscriptions across categories
- **Transactions**: 30-50 sample transactions with dates, amounts, types
- **Offers**: 10-15 bundle offers with discounts and terms
- **Analytics data**: Monthly expense data, category breakdowns, trends

### 5. Interactive Elements

#### Modals/Popups Required:
- Add new subscription
- Edit subscription
- Delete confirmation
- Add money to wallet
- Change password
- Account deletion warning
- Offer details
- Mobile recharge confirmation

#### Form Validations:
- Login form validation
- Password strength checker
- Email format validation
- Amount validations for recharge/funds
- Required field validations

### 6. Visual Requirements

#### Color Scheme:
```css
/* Light Mode */
--bg-primary: #ffffff
--bg-secondary: #f8fafc
--text-primary: #1e293b
--text-secondary: #64748b
--accent: linear-gradient(135deg, #667eea 0%, #764ba2 100%)

/* Dark Mode */
--bg-primary: #0f172a
--bg-secondary: #1e293b
--text-primary: #f1f5f9
--text-secondary: #94a3b8
--accent: linear-gradient(135deg, #667eea 0%, #764ba2 100%)
```

#### Typography:
- Use Inter or similar modern font
- Clear hierarchy with proper font weights
- Responsive font sizes
- Good line spacing for readability

#### Components Style:
- Rounded corners (border-radius: 8-16px)
- Subtle shadows and hover effects
- Gradient accents on buttons and cards
- Smooth transitions (0.2-0.3s)

### 7. Responsive Design

#### Breakpoints:
- Mobile: < 768px (priority)
- Tablet: 768px - 1024px
- Desktop: > 1024px

#### Mobile Optimizations:
- Collapsible sidebar
- Touch-friendly button sizes
- Swipe gestures where appropriate
- Optimized charts for small screens

### 8. Implementation Priorities

#### Must Have (Core Demo):
1. âœ… Login page with theme toggle
2. âœ… Dashboard with charts and metrics
3. âœ… Sidebar navigation
4. âœ… Settings page with theme switcher
5. âœ… Subscriptions list page
6. âœ… Dark/Light mode toggle throughout

#### Should Have (Enhanced Demo):
7. âœ… Funds page with wallet
8. âœ… Regional services page
9. âœ… Add subscription modal
10. âœ… User profile management

#### Nice to Have (Polish):
11. âœ… Bundle offers page
12. âœ… Advanced filtering/sorting
13. âœ… Transaction history
14. âœ… Animations and micro-interactions

### 9. Code Quality Requirements

- **Clean, readable code** with proper component structure
- **Reusable components** (Button, Card, Modal, etc.)
- **Proper error handling** and loading states
- **Accessibility features** (proper ARIA labels, keyboard navigation)
- **Performance optimizations** (avoid unnecessary re-renders)

### 10. Demo Data Examples

```javascript
// Sample subscription data structure
const sampleSubscriptions = [
  {
    id: 1,
    name: "Netflix",
    category: "Entertainment",
    cost: 649,
    billingCycle: "monthly",
    nextBilling: "2025-07-15",
    status: "active",
    icon: "ðŸŽ¬"
  },
  // ... more subscriptions
];

// Sample expense data for charts
const monthlyExpenses = [
  { month: "Jan", amount: 2400 },
  { month: "Feb", amount: 2800 },
  // ... more data
];
```

## Deliverable
Create a single React component artifact that includes:
1. Complete application with all required pages
2. Smooth navigation between sections
3. Working theme toggle
4. Responsive design
5. Sample data for demonstration
6. Professional, polished appearance ready for demo

## Success Criteria
The final application should:
- âœ… Look professional and modern
- âœ… Work smoothly on mobile and desktop
- âœ… Have all core functionality working
- âœ… Include realistic placeholder data
- âœ… Support both dark and light themes
- âœ… Be ready for immediate demo presentation

Start with the login page and dashboard, then implement other sections based on priority. Focus on creating a compelling demo that showcases the product vision effectively.

For the project demo, a proper frontend is what creates the best impression. So, I've made the decision to start with it. I want you to use the `README.md` file for a clear idea of the frontend and backend (currently on hold due to time constraints) of our project. And as we are using flutter with mobile-first approach, I want you to build a good frontend for the project. 

Do the following:
1. For the Home Page, make a Dashboard where the user can look into their subscription expenses for current month and the subscriptions the user had. 
2. Follow a Black and White color palette theme with Dark and Light mode support. Should have gradient feel with a rich font style. 
3. Should have a sidebar where the user can see their profile name and profile picture in the top (in circle), and access other sections like Settings, Subscriptions, Regional Services, Funds, Bundle Offers and Log Out with respective icons.
4. Now for each section:
- Settings: 
. Appearance Section
Theme: Dark, Light, Follow System Theme
Font size: 50 - 200%, Adaptable to system

. Account Settings
Change Password
Delete Account
and other relevant options

. Subscriptions Section
Shows a list of apps you are subscribed to and currently active subscriptions and other related stuffs.

. Regional Services Section
Mobile Recharge (Airtel, JIO, Vodafone)
Regional OTTs

. Funds Section
This section is used to check the current amount being stored as credits and can be redeemed to be used for paying subscriptions. Like a money storage system.

. Bundle Offers
Subscription Offers that the OTT platform owners give during special occasions

. Log Out
Logs out of the app and goes to User Login Page
5. Now for the User Login Page (before the home page) It should show the username and password prompt with a login button. Should have a separate sign up option in the bottom. Make sure to follow the app theme mentioned.
6. Due to time constraints, use placeholders wherever necessary for a good project demo showcase. Will work on backend later to reflect on the demo.
7. Should have popus. You are open to implement it wherever required.

Have to finish this project by tonight, to show the product tomorrow.

## Addressing Current System Issues

### Limitations in Existing Systems

| Problem | Limitation in Current Tools | PCS Solution |
|--------|-----------------------------|--------------|
| Complexity | Tools like Fitcrack require advanced setups (BOINC, GPUs) | Simplified architecture using Python + Flask |
| Ethical Concerns | Real tools use actual password hashes or cracked data | Only synthetic data used in PCS |
| Lack of Transparency | Tools are black-boxed, difficult to understand for learners | Full visibility into queueing, distribution, and logic |
| No Teaching Focus | Designed for performance, not pedagogy | Designed for student-friendly understanding and experimentation |
| Hidden Fault Behavior | Failures handled internally with no explanation | PCS (extensible) can simulate node failures and retries |

The files I have attached is a project that I'm currently working on and have built using AI-tools to code and structure it. The project is about a simplified approach of cracking passwords using Distributed Systems concept and have addressed the issues with current password cracking systems and an attempt to rectify it. The project structure goes like this
common/
- __init.py__
- config.py
- logger.py
master/
- master.py
worker/
- worker.py
data/
- passwords.txt
- hashes.txt
requirements.txt (has flask and requests package)
README.md
gui_dashboard.py
start_pcs.py
I want you to analyze the project repository thoroughly and check for any errors to be fixes, improvements to be made, any suggestions to make the project better. I have only three days for review and planned to complete the code by today. Provide accordingly.
